paragraphs.text: Did I change it? Nope. I always tried to escape my issues. Escaping problems gives you some stamina to face your shitty life again. But you and I both know that problems never go away until you grab them by the root and extinguish them.
paragraphs.name: 3ae0
35de
paragraphs.text: I don’t know. Doesn’t matter, really. What matters is this: If you keep saying yes, you’re living someone else’s life.
But after a few days, there always comes a crash. Big time. I struggle. I can’t get stuff done. I don’ even want to get stuff done.
paragraphs.name: b527

paragraphs.text: I don’t know. Maybe more than you do? We just don’t know until we listen to others.
paragraphs.name: 45fe

paragraphs.text: “Woohoo! I finished college. Goodbye lame old books!”

Checking is a habit that you can never fully eliminate. I still follow the NBA because I like it. Pick only one or two ‘checking’ vices you actually like. Eliminate the rest. You’re not missing anything anyway.
paragraphs.name: c31a

paragraphs.text: What did you write down while you’re reading this article?
paragraphs.name: a76b

paragraphs.text: Get over yourself. Stop worrying. And do something useful.
paragraphs.name: c84a

paragraphs.text: Not writing down your thoughts, ideas, tasks, etc, is stupid. Why? Because you’re wasting a lot of brain power when you rely on your memory.
paragraphs.name: 8f78

d44881605ad1.title: and it’s easy to use work to escape personal problems.

paragraphs.text: and it’s easy to use work to escape personal problems.
paragraphs.name: 35e3

c2c1f8c3d128.title: Okay I have one thing that it keeps beeping here inside when I hear rules.

paragraphs.text: Okay I have one thing that it keeps beeping here inside when I hear rules. Having rules and/or adding more rules to your life besides all that you are living with, makes you more like a robot. You are very very far from that, but the fact is fact. The more algorithm you have the more you will become a droid.

7bbcff963876.title: I notice a lot of fake vetting questions in myself and in others in order to convince ourselves…

paragraphs.text: I notice a lot of fake vetting questions in myself and in others in order to convince ourselves this person can’t have anything useful to offer in terms of advice and to trust ourselves. An example of a fake vetting question would be if someone was trying to help my alignment in yoga and I ask “so, can you do a handstand split?” And then decide they can’t help my alignment.
paragraphs.name: 8b25

paragraphs.text: I love this bit. Made me feel unproductive (more so than the rest of the article), which is obviously the point. Where’s my journal..?
paragraphs.name: a056

paragraphs.text: Goodbye, vocative comma!
Happy to hear that, Lisa!
paragraphs.name: ac6f

paragraphs.text: Hey Darius. Wasn’t it you publishing a post on how to skim through the context of self-teaching guides in almost no time? I might be exaggerating a bit, but by dropping the essay style in favour of lists of does and don’ts you subject your (recent) posts to the very same technique applied by your readers. Loosing readers will then be the next step. Subjective, I know, but it is the way it goes for me.
